body:
personally , I've seen medical Marijuana help people who needed it.  

On the flip side, I've also seen alcohol and opiates destroy lives. 

Let's face it, people who are doping up are probably going to do it despite the legality.  Or are they? 

I can see things like coke or maybe ex legalized,  but should heroin be sold in stores?  

This is an interesting topic indeed

End cannabis prohibition 

Keep heroin, cocaine, and amphetamines illegal

post.title: Ruqqus,  let's talk drug legalization. What are your views?

body:
I'm on the fence with psychedelics, shrooms can lessen depression and I'm all for that, and like you said cannabis can lessen pain for those who need it. The issue is that drugs of that class and marijuana *may* harm those predisposed to schizophrenia. If access to them becomes easier someone who may not have thought of going out of their way before might take it on a whim, and who knows if that person is predisposed. Education on the risks starting in school would be preferable if they are made legal. 

Now on the subject of cocaine and like drugs, I don't see any benefit coming from those other than ruined lives. But I'm kinda pissed at the government rn, mandating masks yet making hard drugs legal in Oregon is just asinine.
body_html:
I'm on the fence with psychedelics, shrooms can lessen depression and I'm all for that, and like you said cannabis can lessen pain for those who need it. The issue is that drugs of that class and marijuana may harm those predisposed to schizophrenia. If access to them becomes easier someone who may not have thought of going out of their way before might take it on a whim, and who knows if that person is predisposed. Education on the risks starting in school would be preferable if they are made legal.

Now on the subject of cocaine and like drugs, I don't see any benefit coming from those other than ruined lives. But I'm kinda pissed at the government rn, mandating masks yet making hard drugs legal in Oregon is just asinine.

So, yes, it's true that alcohol can be abused, but in my opinion, it's not really on the same level as others.

Keep things like coke and meth illegal. Ban opioids too.

Make the minimum age to do drugs 18 (and 16 for beer and wine, like in Germany).

body:
Yeah I strongly oppose that. I’m fairly critical of many popular psychological practices 

On the other hand I might actually be open to making certain prescription medications with little appeal for abuse available over the counter to save people time and money

I’d recommend the writings of Thomas Szasz for people interested in criticisms of both mainstream psychological treatment and our drug policy

“Addiction is a choice” by Schaler is another good book I read that criticized the treatment of drug use as a disease

post.title: Ruqqus,  let's talk drug legalization. What are your views?

body:
I think a lot of people turn to drugs because they’re running away from something. We need to make mental health services more widely available to people like that. The real stuff.  Not big pharma just chucking pills at you. Thats just a different variant of the same problem.

Other than that, lets not give the cops another alibi to trample on our 4’th amendment with, and cartels the ability to leach off of the value of our money. End the ‘Drug War’.

parent.body:
I think a lot of people turn to drugs because they’re running away from something. We need to make mental health services more widely available to people like that. The real stuff.  Not big pharma just chucking pills at you. Thats just a different variant of the same problem.

Other than that, lets not give the cops another alibi to trample on our 4’th amendment with, and cartels the ability to leach off of the value of our money. End the ‘Drug War’.

parent.body:
Yeah I strongly oppose that. I’m fairly critical of many popular psychological practices 

On the other hand I might actually be open to making certain prescription medications with little appeal for abuse available over the counter to save people time and money

I’d recommend the writings of Thomas Szasz for people interested in criticisms of both mainstream psychological treatment and our drug policy

“Addiction is a choice” by Schaler is another good book I read that criticized the treatment of drug use as a disease
parent.body_html:
Yeah I strongly oppose that. I’m fairly critical of many popular psychological practices

On the other hand I might actually be open to making certain prescription medications with little appeal for abuse available over the counter to save people time and money

I’d recommend the writings of Thomas Szasz for people interested in criticisms of both mainstream psychological treatment and our drug policy

“Addiction is a choice” by Schaler is another good book I read that criticized the treatment of drug use as a disease

body:
Anything addictive should be illegal. I extend this also into gacha games that are just gambling without all the red tape. Addiction takes away agency from people.

Then again, I’m also fine with none of it being illegal. There are some things that are supposed to be implicitly policed by your (hopefully not degenerate) society, not explicit laws.

Decriminalize/legalize all. Tax those that are legal. Focus on treatment instead of jail

body: The nanny state is bad in general, and victimless crimes are a ridiculous concept, so legalize everything. Even though that should be argument enough, criminalization also just leads to crime and black markets like alcohol prohibition did. On top of that people will afraid to get help with their drug problems because they will have to throw away decades of their life in prison if they do, so they actually have more incentive to *not* come clean. There's also the "coolness" factor of doing something illegal, especially for teenagers and young adults.

parent.body:
I'm on the fence with psychedelics, shrooms can lessen depression and I'm all for that, and like you said cannabis can lessen pain for those who need it. The issue is that drugs of that class and marijuana *may* harm those predisposed to schizophrenia. If access to them becomes easier someone who may not have thought of going out of their way before might take it on a whim, and who knows if that person is predisposed. Education on the risks starting in school would be preferable if they are made legal. 

Now on the subject of cocaine and like drugs, I don't see any benefit coming from those other than ruined lives. But I'm kinda pissed at the government rn, mandating masks yet making hard drugs legal in Oregon is just asinine.
parent.body_html:
I'm on the fence with psychedelics, shrooms can lessen depression and I'm all for that, and like you said cannabis can lessen pain for those who need it. The issue is that drugs of that class and marijuana may harm those predisposed to schizophrenia. If access to them becomes easier someone who may not have thought of going out of their way before might take it on a whim, and who knows if that person is predisposed. Education on the risks starting in school would be preferable if they are made legal.

Now on the subject of cocaine and like drugs, I don't see any benefit coming from those other than ruined lives. But I'm kinda pissed at the government rn, mandating masks yet making hard drugs legal in Oregon is just asinine.

body:
If you have no need. Dont create one.
  
Look i have some, wicked depression. Oddly enough, the cure is a depressant, weed. I say cure, i mean plaster. Because one does not cure mental wounds, one works around.
  
If you are well. Dont fall in this trap.
  
I need it, im an outlier, a strange case where things dont act like normal.
  
Most people with depression, will go deeper in it with weed. 
  
And alcohol, is straight up poison. Kills more than corona virus, yet perfectly legal to consume.
  
Kills more than smoking, yet snoking has more regulations, and no the regulations did not reduce death by smoking.
   
Dont drink alcohol. The buzz is overhyped, not that pleasant and the risks are much higher. Vomitting, headache, dizziness, dehydration... 

You know what i get from smoking? High. Burn some braincells, and voila. The price of entry is clear.
  
Alcohol takes your better judgement, it takes your standards, takes your body, mind and likely also your car.
  
Because its the most available potent drug. As it is but rot of sugar.

body:
Drugs aren't the problem. People are the problem. People who abuse drugs to self medicate need to get professional help. Education is needed not banning drugs.

Perhaps if we tax drugs, and the drug money funds Education and Mental Health facilities I would be down for that.

I've done drugs, but stopped when it became a problem. I dont use anymore because I realized my problems still existed after the high, and usually the drugs just made my problem worse. Also, now that my problems are fixed, I dont have the urge to use anymore. I'm cool around people who use, but I don't partake anymore.

post.title: Ruqqus,  let's talk drug legalization. What are your views?

body: With things such as drugs, people tend to only focus on the bad things drugs do, rather than the good ones. For every drug addict that has their life ruined as a result of drugs, there's a businessman who made a living or a wealthy saver who came up from nothing. You can't just focus on one end or the other. There's a small group of people who will extremely benefit from selling recreational drugs, a small group who will be extremely harmed, and a big group in the middle that's just exchanging the money they have for something they want more, creating value as with any good or service in a free market. Enacting blanket prohibition and throwing tens of millions of people who take drugs in a concrete prison cell for years is one step shy of a crime against humanity. You might as well ban video games, sports cars, or sugary foods. For these reasons, I believe that all drugs should legal and largely unregulated, so as to prevent cronyism.
body_html: With things such as drugs, people tend to only focus on the bad things drugs do, rather than the good ones. For every drug addict that has their life ruined as a result of drugs, there's a businessman who made a living or a wealthy saver who came up from nothing. You can't just focus on one end or the other. There's a small group of people who will extremely benefit from selling recreational drugs, a small group who will be extremely harmed, and a big group in the middle that's just exchanging the money they have for something they want more, creating value as with any good or service in a free market. Enacting blanket prohibition and throwing tens of millions of people who take drugs in a concrete prison cell for years is one step shy of a crime against humanity. You might as well ban video games, sports cars, or sugary foods. For these reasons, I believe that all drugs should legal and largely unregulated, so as to prevent cronyism.

Health care should be privatized and instead of subsidizing insurance maybe the USA should subsidize actual health care or better yet maybe get rid of the shitty unions preventing cheaper healthcare. But yes some services shouldn’t be private some should. Like why would I want government subsidized airlines? Why would I have to purchase police protection? There needs to be a balance and that balance is more sectors being private not all but most.

body:
There needs to be a re-scheduling, an end to the war on drugs. 

Rescheduling has to take into account everything we know now about addiction. Keep plenty of things a felony, but schedule according to immediate risk to the public. Ask why it should be illegal, rather than why it should be legalized. 

An end to the war on drugs means the straits are far less dire for drug criminals, hopefully alleviating some of the violence surrounding drug culture, as well as not soaking up billions of taxpayer dollars on a surreptitious war with Mexico. 

Those two things should solve much of the illegal drug problem, and actually making big pharma pretend like it has an idea about what ethical standards are would go 5he rest of the way in solving the drug problem, but also allowing for people to therapeutically or recreationally use these amazing substances.
body_html:
There needs to be a re-scheduling, an end to the war on drugs.

Rescheduling has to take into account everything we know now about addiction. Keep plenty of things a felony, but schedule according to immediate risk to the public. Ask why it should be illegal, rather than why it should be legalized.

An end to the war on drugs means the straits are far less dire for drug criminals, hopefully alleviating some of the violence surrounding drug culture, as well as not soaking up billions of taxpayer dollars on a surreptitious war with Mexico.

Those two things should solve much of the illegal drug problem, and actually making big pharma pretend like it has an idea about what ethical standards are would go 5he rest of the way in solving the drug problem, but also allowing for people to therapeutically or recreationally use these amazing substances.

post.body:
personally , I've seen medical Marijuana help people who needed it.  

On the flip side, I've also seen alcohol and opiates destroy lives. 

Let's face it, people who are doping up are probably going to do it despite the legality.  Or are they? 

I can see things like coke or maybe ex legalized,  but should heroin be sold in stores?  

This is an interesting topic indeed

post.title: Ruqqus,  let's talk drug legalization. What are your views?

body:
decriminalize all drugs, there is no reason someone should be convicted of a victimless crime such as drugs. 

legalization of all drugs would be a great next step, regulation needs to be paramount in terms of product quality. there should be no reason to perpetuate adulterated drugs with harmful additives after decriminalizing them. this in turn would cut down cartels and violent gangs on a massive scale, while also keeping drugs out of reach of children. 

i dont know about you, but as a teen, I was able to get hard drugs A LOT easier than alcohol. i had to wait for my friend to turn 21 who was a like 3 years older than me, and it wasn't all the time. but he had shit like coke and xans easily. legalizing prevents children from acquiring the drugs imo. 

a lot of people have addictive personalities, and I can see where the argument against this comes in. on the contrary though, I'd rather eliminate drugs from violent criminals hands as a mean for profit. there should be excessive amounts of warnings if drugs were to be legalized.

legalize everything. heroin, coke, xtc, xans, addys, meth, weed, there is no reason victimless crimes should be punishable by law.

a lot of people have addictive personalities, and I can see where the argument against this comes in. on the contrary though, I'd rather eliminate drugs from violent criminals hands as a mean for profit. there should be excessive amounts of warnings if drugs were to be legalized.

legalize everything. heroin, coke, xtc, xans, addys, meth, weed, there is no reason victimless crimes should be punishable by law.

parent.body:
I'm on the fence with psychedelics, shrooms can lessen depression and I'm all for that, and like you said cannabis can lessen pain for those who need it. The issue is that drugs of that class and marijuana *may* harm those predisposed to schizophrenia. If access to them becomes easier someone who may not have thought of going out of their way before might take it on a whim, and who knows if that person is predisposed. Education on the risks starting in school would be preferable if they are made legal. 

Now on the subject of cocaine and like drugs, I don't see any benefit coming from those other than ruined lives. But I'm kinda pissed at the government rn, mandating masks yet making hard drugs legal in Oregon is just asinine.
parent.body_html:
I'm on the fence with psychedelics, shrooms can lessen depression and I'm all for that, and like you said cannabis can lessen pain for those who need it. The issue is that drugs of that class and marijuana may harm those predisposed to schizophrenia. If access to them becomes easier someone who may not have thought of going out of their way before might take it on a whim, and who knows if that person is predisposed. Education on the risks starting in school would be preferable if they are made legal.

Now on the subject of cocaine and like drugs, I don't see any benefit coming from those other than ruined lives. But I'm kinda pissed at the government rn, mandating masks yet making hard drugs legal in Oregon is just asinine.

I think a lot of people turn to drugs because they’re running away from something. We need to make mental health services more widely available to people like that. The real stuff.  Not big pharma just chucking pills at you. Thats just a different variant of the same problem.

Other than that, lets not give the cops another alibi to trample on our 4’th amendment with, and cartels the ability to leach off of the value of our money. End the ‘Drug War’.

body:
I hate drugs, I would want nothing more than to have them all go "extinct", however I also know that some people need it. So, I'd say legalise it, but only for medical use. I think rehab should be the goal to send all addicted users to, instead of jail; at least as a first and second chance.

In my country you have to get alcohol from a government mandated shop, and I like that. I think however that it should be recorded how much you buy and should have a limit to how many boxes of wine you're allowed to buy per week. I would have a different view on this if I didnt grow up with an alcoholic parent:), so please no hate.

body: What you described is still mental health. It may not be a disorder yet but having those feelings consistently can lead to something like depression or anxiety. Its my belief that regulating your outside environment is just as important as controlling your temperament. The reason why we see so many disorders today is because, in today’s society of ‘manufactured humans’, theres no need for our brains to produce as many happy chemicals, like dopamine and serotonin like it did when we lived the historical lifestyle full of activity and chores, that we evolved for. Your brain, like any muscle, will atrophy its strengths to conserve energy for survival. So if you find yourself in a life situation that brings general unhappiness, you can bet, ironically enough, that your brain isn’t going to waste its time producing those said ‘happy chemicals’ as much anymore. I think this is why we see higher rates of depression and suicides as time goes on and people become less independent, and more dependent on the system. This is why real therapy, meditation, guidance, a nutritious diet, and discipline is important. Happy pills wont cut it. If anything, I think pacifying people only represses their will to improve even more. People inherently want to self actualize and be sovereign individuals.

body:
That mirrors my sentiments too.  I've seen far FAR too many lives and communities destroyed by opioids.  Especially communities that enable opioid use and decriminalize the petty crime.

Addicts are a net negative to society in every measurable metric and should be deincentivised via criminalization.  I'm fine with charitable organizations and civil organizations who direct donations and tax money towards healing, but needle exchanges aren't healing.  At the end of the day, healing addiction is a personal choice made by the addict.  That requires a rock bottom.  Not a crime ridden cesspit.

I'm fine with charitable organizations and civil organizations who direct donations and tax money towards healing, but needle exchanges aren't healing. At the end of the day, healing addiction is a personal choice made by the addict. That requires a rock bottom. Not a crime ridden cesspit.

parent.body:
That mirrors my sentiments too.  I've seen far FAR too many lives and communities destroyed by opioids.  Especially communities that enable opioid use and decriminalize the petty crime.

Addicts are a net negative to society in every measurable metric and should be deincentivised via criminalization.  I'm fine with charitable organizations and civil organizations who direct donations and tax money towards healing, but needle exchanges aren't healing.  At the end of the day, healing addiction is a personal choice made by the addict.  That requires a rock bottom.  Not a crime ridden cesspit.

post.title: Ruqqus,  let's talk drug legalization. What are your views?

body: There will always be exceptions to the rule. And even if something is illegal, like certain pills without a prescription, people will find a way. The only benefit of restricting certain drugs is to lessen the destructive impact on society at large. It's like a border wall, it will never be 100% effective, but it will also be greater than 0% effective.

body:
In my limited second-hand anecdotal experience, needle exchanges are co-opted by idealists who just hand them out instead of legitimate exchanges.  I have several friends who moved to the left coast 10+ years ago and watched the rapid decline.

IMO if you are deep enough into addiction that life ending diseases don't factor into your decision making, then your personal choices have made you too great of a burden to society.  That's difficult enough to swallow as-is.  Combine that with a political environment that decriminalizes petty crime and treats addicts like a protected class and you have a recipe for societal rot.

body:
Yes, and I have depression, and i have people who work in the domain.
  
That right there is bullshit. Same way i heard some folks say weed can help with depression. It does with me, but im a medical anomaly. For 90% of the world, depression mixes with medication and nothing else ever. Because guess what marijuana is? A depressant, and your body already struggles to make you feel ok.
   
So apply this now to psychedelics. What do they do? Well mostly make you hallucinate through a variety of chemical reactions. A common companion of depression is anxiety. Imagination from hallucinagenics+ anxiety.
  
There's only so many bad trips i need to witness before ii have to put my foot down and tell you folks. No.

In experiments,  its worked on those to whom normal treatment failed. But like me, outliers.

body:
Freedom first.

Legalize it all.  Tax it just enough to pay for treatment and advertising campaigns that detail the dangers of drugs, like how easy it is to kill yourself with heroin.  Don't need the government becoming the new drug dealers, using drugs as their new honey pot.  While we're at it legalize prostitution, person's choice if they want to sell themselves.  In the short term, the Mexican gangs will become more violent as they try to replace their dried up drug money with more kidnapping and turf wars, but in the long term they themselves will dry up.  Whoever is left will probably enter politics for a new legal life of stealing from people.

parent.body:
Yes, and I have depression, and i have people who work in the domain.
  
That right there is bullshit. Same way i heard some folks say weed can help with depression. It does with me, but im a medical anomaly. For 90% of the world, depression mixes with medication and nothing else ever. Because guess what marijuana is? A depressant, and your body already struggles to make you feel ok.
   
So apply this now to psychedelics. What do they do? Well mostly make you hallucinate through a variety of chemical reactions. A common companion of depression is anxiety. Imagination from hallucinagenics+ anxiety.
  
There's only so many bad trips i need to witness before ii have to put my foot down and tell you folks. No.

In experiments,  its worked on those to whom normal treatment failed. But like me, outliers.

body:
Used to be anti-drug because it increases societal cohesion to not have drugs.

Nowadays, I'm more realistic and understand societal cohesion is not coming back, and that ship has sailed. We'll also never become an ethnostate and crack down on foreign and domestic drug production, so that's a lost cause in modern, REAL LIFE society.

Legalize them, so people like me who don't care about the long haul anyway can buy ourselves some ice or nose candy, instead of relying on alcohol to feel our weekend doses of happiness.

body:
I don't know where this "depressant makes you more depressed" thing came from. Depression has nothing to do with CNS depression, but keep on claiming you know what you're talking about.

Hallucinating CAN make people anxious, but to claim that a stressful high is going to worsen someone's depression when there's tons of research stating the opposite, that LSD and other psychedelics cure depression is wrong.

post.body:
personally , I've seen medical Marijuana help people who needed it.  

On the flip side, I've also seen alcohol and opiates destroy lives. 

Let's face it, people who are doping up are probably going to do it despite the legality.  Or are they? 

I can see things like coke or maybe ex legalized,  but should heroin be sold in stores?  

This is an interesting topic indeed

post.title: Ruqqus,  let's talk drug legalization. What are your views?

body:
Softer drugs like cannabis should be fully legalised and taxed. Some of these are less or equally harmful to already legal drugs like tobacco and alcohol.

Harder narcotics like cocaine, heroin and PCP should remain illegal to distribute. Their mere possession should be decriminalised and funds spent on the War on Drugs should be diverted towards rehabilitation programs.

Softer drugs like cannabis should be fully legalised and taxed. Some of these are less or equally harmful to already legal drugs like tobacco and alcohol.
